results.title: The Present from Gondwanaland
results.creator_credit: Mike Weatherley and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Up a gum tree”.
Two hundred million years ago the giant continent Gondwanaland split and Australia drifted away. Its plants and animals evolved in isolation from the rest of the world. How does a tree used as a prison fit into the story and what are the secrets of the gum tree’s success? Narrated by David Bellamy.

results.title: The Landscape architects; Fire down below
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Up a gum tree”.
The Landscape architects David Bellamy looks at how Aborigines learned to tame the countryside without becoming farmers, and at what sort of diet they enjoyed. “Fire Down Below” David Bellamy looks at the secrets of survival of the Australian flora against the frequent fires which seek to destroy.

results.title: Not so much a desert, more a way of life
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Up a gum tree”.
Much of the surface of Australia is described as desert. But is this a true description? Wherever he looks, David Bellamy finds life among the sand and rocks.

results.title: The Landscape architects
results.creator_credit: Mike Weatherley and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Up a gum tree”.
Australia owes a great debt to the Aboriginals who learned to tame the inhospitable countryside. But why did they never become farmers and what sort of diet did the first Australians enjoy? David Bellamy attempts to find out the answers to these questions.

results.title: The Great Barriers
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Up a gum tree”.
Australia’s coasts are battleground’s where seaweeds, coral and mangroves fight for survival against the ravages of the ocean - a survival that is vital to the protection of the coast.

results.title: Fire down below
results.creator_credit: Mike Weatherley and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Up a gum tree”.
David Bellamy celebrates Christmas in Australia. Instead of holly a banksia decorates his Christmas pudding, and, as the brandy burns, the plant provides clues to the secrets of survival of the Australian flora against the frequent fires which seek to destroy it. Narrated by David Bellamy.

results.title: Hidden treasures
results.creator_credit: David Gill, Kevin Brownlow and Thames Production
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Unknown Chaplin”.
Featuring Charlie Chaplin in previously unseen home movies, scenes from abandoned films and scenes cut from release prints of the classics “City Lights” and “Modern Times”. Narrated by James Mason.

results.title: The Great director
results.creator_credit: David Gill, Kevin Brownlow and Thames Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Unknown Chaplin”.
The second of a trilogy throwing new light on Chaplin’s career in films. In 1917 he became independent and built his own studio. Stills, camera tests and rushes are organised to produce new insights into his famous classics, “The Kid”, “The Gold Rush” and “City Lights”. Narrated by James Mason. Rated: G

results.title: My happiest years
results.creator_credit: David Gill, Kevin Brownlow and Thames Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Unknown Chaplin”.
The first of a trilogy throwing new light on Chaplin’s career in films. This part covers the period in which he made twelve 2 reel comedies. Using footage selected from previously uncut rushes, the progression of Chaplin’s ideas is uncovered and insight is given into his working methods. Narrated by James Mason. Rated: G
results.creator_credit_for_label: David Gill, Kevin Brownlow and Thames Television
